为什么世界各地的摄影师似乎都痴迷于 24-70mm 镜头？无论您是刚刚开始拍摄还是已经拍摄了一段时间，您都可能遇到过 24-70mm 镜头，了解这款镜头如此受欢迎的原因以及您可能想要考虑投资的原因非常重要合二为一。

下面，我将带您了解 24-70mm 镜头的特别之处。您将了解为什么它是各种摄影的绝佳选择、它的技术方面以及一些充分利用它的实用技巧。我还分享了大量 24-70mm 照片示例，以便您知道购买后会发生什么。

让我们开始吧。

什么是24-70mm镜头？

您可能听说过摄影师对 24-70mm 镜头赞不绝口——这是有充分理由的。让我们深入了解一下这个镜头到底是什么。

24-70mm镜头并不完全是广角镜头，也不是长焦镜头。这就是通常所说的标准变焦或广角到长焦变焦。为什么？因为它从24mm的广角焦距开始，一直到70mm的短焦距。这是一款在一个包装中涵盖了很多内容的镜头。

如果您使用的是 APS-C 相机，情况会有所不同。 APS-C 相机上的 24-70mm 镜头可提供大约 35-105mm 的有效焦距。换句话说，它淡化了广角视角，让您在长距离上有更多的视野。

24-70mm 变焦非常受欢迎。事实上，我想说它是爱好者和专业人士使用的最常见的变焦镜头之一（如果不是最常见的话）。它因其惊人的多功能性、令人印象深刻的光学效果和出色的设计而成为许多人的首选镜头。

生产这些镜头的不仅仅是一两家制造商。镜头界的所有大牌都提供 24-70mm 玻璃，这足以说明它在摄影中的重要性。

24-70mm 摄影的常见主题

24-70mm 镜头用途广泛，因此可用于多种场景的拍摄。以下是这款镜头真正闪耀的一些类型：

人像摄影： 24-70mm 镜头可以拍摄令人惊叹的广角人像以及全身姿势和特写头像。它还可以防止您在拍摄时需要更换镜头。想象一下您可以与拍摄对象保持流动和联系，而无需停下来更换玻璃。

婚礼和活动摄影： 24-70mm 焦距范围可实现更宽和更紧凑的构图，因此您可以使用 24mm 捕捉婚礼的盛况，然后使用 70mm 放大拍摄新娘和新郎的亲密照片。计划拍摄室内或夜间活动？该镜头的 f/2.8 版本可确保在具有挑战性的照明条件下提供高质量的图像。

风景摄影：虽然24mm端不能提供许多风景拍摄者所喜爱的超广角视角，但它仍然提供了相当宽的视野。想象一下令人惊叹的山脉或广阔的沙漠；您可以使用 24 毫米拍摄整个区域，然后放大到 50 毫米或 70 毫米以获得更亲密的构图。

静物摄影： 24-70mm镜头在拍摄食物、产品和其他静物物体时也能派上用场；正如我在下面更详细地探讨的那样，这些镜头往往提供令人惊讶的可靠近距对焦功能。另外，光学器件非常锐利——在进行特写摄影时总是有好处！

底线：24-70mm 镜头不会限制您进行特定类型的摄影，它就像将多个镜头合而为一。无论您是要捕捉面孔、事件还是自然之美，这款镜头都能满足您的需求并提供无限的创意可能性。

24-70mm f/2.8 与 24-70mm f/4 镜头

如果您正在考虑购买第一支 24-70mm 镜头，您可能会对众多选择感到困惑。也许您正在努力决定购买哪个版本。让我帮你把事情弄清楚。

24-70mm 镜头通常有两种版本：f/2.8 和 f/4。这个数字指的是镜头提供的最大光圈：f/2.8版本可以使用更宽的f/2.8光圈，而f/4版本只能将光圈扩大到f/4。因此，与 f/4 版本相比，f/2.8 版本可以吸收更多光线。

24-70mm f/2.8 和 f/4 镜头之间的光学差异可能看起来并不大。对于一些摄影师来说，事实并非如此。但在某些特定情况下它可能非常重要。在 f/2.8 和 f/4 镜头之间进行选择时，您需要考虑一些额外的后果。

首先，由于f/2.8版本可以收集更多光线，因此可以在较暗的场景中获得更好的手持图像。得益于光线增强，您无需降低快门速度或提高 ISO ，这意味着您可以拍摄更清晰、噪音更少的图像。 （这就是许多婚礼和活动摄影师只使用 24-70mm f/2.8 的原因。）

其次，更宽的光圈会产生更浅的景深效果，因此 f/2.8 版本可以实现更强烈的背景散景。这在人像摄影中尤其重要。如果您认真对待肖像，我建议您购买 24-70mm f/2.8，而不是 24-70mm f/4。使用 f/4 镜头还能产生漂亮的背景模糊效果吗？是的，但是做起来会困难得多，而且通常看起来不会那么好。

另一方面，这些大光圈变焦镜头确实比窄光圈变焦镜头更重。而且它们的价格要高得多。

因此，除非您特别需要 f/2.8 版本的 24-70mm 镜头用于手持低光拍摄或背景散景效果，否则最好选择 f/4 版本。它将为您带来相同的结果——价格减半，重量减半。

在这两个版本之间做出正确的选择需要您知道自己想要什么。考虑您的拍摄风格、主题和预算。这两种选择都有其优点，了解它们将引导您找到适合您摄影需求的完美 24-70mm 镜头。

应使用 24-70mm 镜头的原因

24-70mm 镜头尚未发售？没问题！以下是我喜欢 24-70mm 玻璃的几个原因：

1.没有学习曲线

24-70mm 镜头的焦距从广角延伸到短焦距，但其大部分范围位于标准焦距点，与人眼密切对应。因此，要使用24-70mm镜头，您不需要学习以不同的方式看东西；相反，通过 24-70mm 观看，您将获得非常自然的视野。

事实上，当你按照眼睛看到的方式进行拍摄时，学习构图会容易得多。您可以发现有趣的拍摄对象，将相机放在眼前，然后拍摄——而超广角镜头和长焦镜头则迫使您思考视野、 畸变、 压缩以及它们如何改变场景。

即使是 24mm，畸变也是有限的。这样您就可以进行广角摄影，而不必担心广角效果。在 70 毫米处，您可以放大以获得更紧凑的构图，同时仍然捕捉相对中性的视角。

另外，50mm 焦距非常适合人像摄影：不会太长而失去亲密感，也不会太宽而拉伸拍摄对象。反而是刚刚好。

2. 24-70mm镜头提供近距离对焦

24-70mm 镜头是为标准尺寸的拍摄对象设计的，对吧？

嗯，是的……也不是。

您会发现，虽然这些镜头通常是在考虑肖像、风景和自然主题的情况下创建的，但它们还提供令人印象深刻的近距离对焦功能。最近对焦距离确实因型号而异，但一般在 15 英寸（38 厘米）左右。

换句话说，您可以使用 24-70mm 镜头拍摄令人惊叹的特写镜头 - 花朵、树叶、人像细节等。尤其令人兴奋的是 24-70mm 镜头的灵活性；如果您正在拍摄肖像主题，您可以后退一步拍摄漂亮的全身照片，稍微移近拍摄头部和肩膀构图，然后再靠近拍摄拍摄对象的眼睛、耳朵或身体的细节照片。衣服。

活动摄影师始终使用这种近距离对焦的灵活性。缩小拍摄婚礼宾客的镜头，介入拍摄中心装饰品的镜头，缩小拍摄天花板的镜头，介入拍摄现场布置的镜头。

如果你喜欢拍摄风景，你可以用 24 毫米拍摄一览无余的风景，然后放大到 70 毫米，近距离拍摄岩石、沙纹等细节。

这么方便，全归功于24-70mm镜头的力量。

3. 焦距范围极其广泛

我已经谈到过这一点，但它可以说是 24-70mm 镜头最重要的优点，因此值得单独专门讨论这一点。

您会发现，使用 24-70mm 镜头，您可以以多种不同焦距进行拍摄，从广角到标准再到长焦，这个范围在面对高要求的照片拍摄时提供了无限的可能性。

首先，在进行单张照片拍摄时，您可以轻松地从广角切换到变焦，并随着场景和拍摄对象的变化而快速调整。而且您根本不需要切换镜头，这将保持拍摄流程完整，并防止您在从一个镜头切换到下一个镜头时错过关键时刻。

此外，24-70mm 镜头的多功能性意味着您可以只用它来工作，即使您在世界各地巡游拍摄和度假时也是如此。想象一下，你的包里只有一个镜头去拍摄照片。很好，对吧？

4. 结构坚固且舒适

大多数 24-70mm 镜头都非常坚固，结构坚固，经久耐用。制造商知道这些是“随身携带”镜头，因此他们确保 24-70mm 能够应对您可能遇到的任何情况，从雨雪到风沙和灰尘。

如果您经常在沙漠、瀑布附近或海滩拍摄，那么 24-70mm 镜头将成为您的救星，让您捕捉各种构图，而不必担心损坏您宝贵的光学器件。当然，您应该始终进行适当的镜片护理；我不建议您将镜头掉入水中、让它浸泡等。但就镜头而言，24-70mm 的选择往往非常可靠。

（您还需要一台精良的相机；虽然 24-70mm 镜头很棒，但它们无法保护您的相机电子设备！）

此外，24-70mm 镜头的手感极佳。它们不会太长，让你几个小时后就会感到疲倦，也不会太短，让你没有什么可以抓握的。您可以舒适地使用 24-70mm 镜头进行一整天的拍摄，并且您将始终感觉自己正在使用真正的固体镜头。

5. 尺寸和重量几乎适合所有东西

平均而言，24-70 毫米镜头的尺寸约为 3.3 x 3.3 x 4.9 英寸（8.4 x 8.4 x 12.4 厘米），重量约为 2 磅（900 克）。

虽然这些镜头并不小，但它们当然也不大，也不重。它们几乎适合您遇到的任何相机包，即使它们连接到相机上 - 因此您可以轻松地将您的设备放在肩带包或背包中。另外，由于 24-70mm 镜头非常短，因此您可以将相机挂在脖子上，而不会感觉自己拿着一块砖头。

事实上，我的 50mm (f/1.2) 镜头比 24-70mm 镜头更重，尽管它更短。我什至设法将我的相机和 24-70mm 镜头放在一个普通的旧钱包中（在很多情况下可以派上用场）。

底线：24-70mm 镜头的尺寸适合各种类型的摄影冒险，从山区徒步旅行到城市休闲漫步，再到全球旅行摄影。

使用 24-70mm 镜头的技巧

您已经拥有 24-70mm 镜头并且很高兴使用它。但在开始拍摄之前，有一些提示和技巧可以帮助您充分利用这款镜头：

1. 练习在各个焦距下使用镜头

首先，确保您了解镜头范围（24 毫米至 70 毫米）中每个焦距的功能。

花一些时间尝试不同的焦距。看看它们如何影响你的作品。

尝试用 24 毫米、35 毫米、50 毫米、70 毫米拍摄单个主体。在计算机上调出图像并并排观察它们。问问自己：每个焦距如何改变拍摄对象的视图？

很快，您甚至在通过取景器查看之前就会了解每个焦距的外观。您不会浪费宝贵的时间来放大和缩小来寻找完美的镜头。

2.观察失真情况

当使用 24-70mm 镜头的广角端拍摄时，您可能会注意到一些失真。

这意味着直线看起来会收敛，靠近镜头的物体可能看起来有点拉伸或倾斜。

像这样的扭曲（称为透视扭曲）并不总是坏事，它可以在艺术上发挥巨大的效果。但重要的是要高度意识到它的影响，因为如果你不小心，它可能会导致照片不好看。

如果您想尽量减少 24 毫米处的畸变，请确保拍摄对象距离镜头前部适当远，并尽力保持镜头与地面平行（即，不要向上或向下倾斜）。

3.不要过分依赖变焦

变焦镜头让人忍不住站在一个地方，只需转动镜筒即可改变构图。虽然 24-70mm 镜头的变焦功能非常棒且非常有用，但它并不能取代物理上靠近拍摄对象的需要。

其一，四处走动可以帮助你微调你的作品。而且它还可以给你一个完全不同的视角。

因此，要养成结合使用移动和焦距调整的习惯。这样，您将获得最佳结果并发现您可能会错过的观点。

请记住，摄影不仅与焦距有关，还与摄影师的运动和身体姿势有关！

4.打开图像稳定功能

许多 24-70mm 镜头都具有图像稳定功能。这是一个方便的小功能，有助于抵消相机抖动；这样，您就可以以 1/20 秒至 1/60 秒范围内的较慢快门速度手持拍摄，这在夜间人像拍摄和室内活动等弱光场景中特别有用。

因此，每当您拍摄相对静止的拍摄对象并且无法使用三脚架（或者您根本不想使用三脚架）时，请打开图像稳定功能。

也就是说，有一些注意事项需要牢记。首先，如果您使用三脚架，请确保关闭图像稳定功能。否则，您可能会发现它实际上增加了照片的模糊度。

其次，请注意图像稳定通常无法帮助您拍摄移动物体的清晰照片。为此，您需要较高的快门速度。

5.观看背景

24-70mm 镜头可能不被认为是真正的广角镜头，但它仍然提供一些宽焦距，尤其是在 24-50mm 范围内。在拍摄广角构图时，您可能会注意到，即使您使用大光圈，照片中的背景通常也会变得相对清晰。

这对你来说意味着什么？

这意味着您需要仔细注意主题背后发生的事情。分散注意力的背景很容易将焦点从主要拍摄对象上转移开。也许它是街景中的一个明亮标志，或者是自然照片中伸出的一根树枝。无论是什么，您都需要努力让它远离您的镜头。

如果您发现自己所在的区域背景可能会引起一些问题，请尝试围绕拍摄对象移动。向右或向左走，从低处走，甚至如果可以的话，爬到高处。这一切都是为了找到合适的角度，让您的拍摄对象在没有任何背景干扰的情况下发光。

6.考虑使用镜头滤镜进行保护

投资一个好的 24-70mm 镜头可能是一笔不小的开支。这样的镜头通常光学性能极佳，您需要尽可能地爱护它。

这就是为什么我建议在镜头前添加紫外线滤镜或透明滤镜。它可以保护您珍贵的玻璃免受意外碰撞或意外的手指污迹。

因此，如果您打算花大量时间使用 24-70mm 镜头，请考虑投资购买优质的镜头滤镜。这是一个简单的步骤，但可以在保证镜头安全和图像呈现最佳效果方面大有帮助。

Lightroom 与 Lightroom Classic：哪个适合您？首先出现在数码摄影学校。它的作者是西蒙·林斯穆斯 ( Simon Ringsmuth) 。

Lightroom 长期以来一直是数字摄影社区的中坚力量，但了解 Lightroom Classic 与 Lightroom 之间的差异可能有点棘手。这两个程序都非常适合组织和编辑您的所有数码照片，并且每月的价格相同。

然而，Lightroom 和 Lightroom Classic 具有独特的优势和关键差异，可以对您的编辑工作流程产生巨大的影响。对于您的独特需求，一个程序可能会比另一个更好，对它们有更多了解将帮助您决定哪个程序适合您 - 这就是本文派上用场的地方！

一些背景

在数字摄影的早期，Adobe Photoshop 和 Corel PaintShop Pro 等新兴编辑应用程序允许摄影师编辑、更改和以其他方式处理他们的图像。这个过程通常是缓慢而艰苦的，但随着时间的推移，这些类型的程序得到了改进——现在它们是行业中不可或缺的工具。

然而，随着数字摄影的普及和图像库激增至数万和数十万个文件，很明显，摄影师需要的不仅仅是编辑解决方案。他们需要数字资产管理解决方案。

Adobe 在 2007 年发布了 Photoshop Lightroom，解决了这个问题，这是一款一体化程序，可以处理真正的端到端数字摄影工作流程的每个元素：导入、组织、编辑和导出。虽然它的编辑选项套件并不像传统的 Photoshop 那样全面，但它很快成为那些想要一个程序来管理和调整所有数字图像的摄影师的实际解决方案。

十年后，当 Adob​​e 从头开始​​重写 Lightroom 以满足现代摄影师不断变化的需求时，一切再次发生了变化。该公司保留了传统的 Lightroom，但将其更名为“Lightroom Classic”，并将新程序命名为“Lightroom CC”。最近，Adobe 从新程序的名称中删除了“CC”，将其改为“Lightroom”。

这两个程序继续被全球数百万摄影师使用，并且 Adob​​e 定期更新新功能和工具，以帮助摄影师充分利用他们的数字图像。

Lightroom Classic 概述

Lightroom Classic 是自 2007 年以来经过考验的 Lightroom 版本。它围绕基于桌面的工作流程构建，允许摄影师将图像从相机直接复制到本地存储介质（如外部硬盘驱动器）上，将它们组织在库模块，并在开发模块中编辑它们。它包括地图、书籍、幻灯片、打印和网络等其他模块，对于许多在为客户创建附加产品和服务时依赖该程序的摄影师来说非常有用。

Lightroom Classic 有点像一辆旧皮卡车：它并不华丽，而且到处都有一些奇怪的怪癖，但它可以满足大多数人需要的一切，并且总能完成工作。当 Adob​​e 发布 Lightroom 并将其现有程序更名为 Lightroom Classic 时，摄影界普遍猜测该公司将取消 Classic 版本并强制每个人都使用新的 Lightroom。

幸运的是，情况并非如此，Lightroom Classic 继续定期更新新功能，例如自适应预设、 基于 AI 的遮罩和AI 驱动的噪声消除，以及对所有最新相机和镜头的支持。虽然 Lightroom Classic 不像基于云的同类产品那么时尚和花哨，但它是一个可靠的强大工具，为大多数摄影师提供了足够的工具。

Lightroom Classic 专业版

  • 数百万摄影师数字资产管理的黄金标准
  • 广泛的编辑工具，几乎涵盖了人们可能需要的所有内容
  • 为拥有海量照片库的摄影师提供丰富、深入的组织选项
  • 在 Photoshop 或第三方应用程序等外部工具中轻松编辑图像
  • 相册可以在网络上共享并与 Lightroom 应用程序同步

Lightroom Classic 的缺点

  • 专为基于桌面的环境而设计，图像存储在本地而不是云端
  • 用户界面令人困惑
  • 即使在高规格计算机上，书籍创建和面部识别等一些工具也非常慢
  • 用户负责创建和维护所有图像的备份

Lightroom 概述

2017 年，Adobe 将 Lightroom Classic 中人们逐渐喜爱和依赖的许多功能放入新的应用程序中：Lightroom。它与其前身同名，但从一开始就被设计为以云为中心、适合移动设备，并准备好满足越来越多成长过程中不依赖桌面存储的摄影师的需求。

如果 Lightroom Classic 是一匹值得信赖的驮骡，那么 Lightroom 就是一匹时尚的年轻赛马。虽然它没有 Lightroom Classic 那样的功能深度或用户数量，但其云优先设计、令人印象深刻的手机和平板电脑支持以及像Discover这样的集成功能赢得了想要做更多事情的新一代摄影师的青睐与他们的数字图像。

除了全新的用户界面之外，Lightroom 还彻底重新构想了数码照片存储的理念。 Lightroom 不是将图像保存在计算机或外部硬盘上，而是将所有图像导入到云端并将它们存储在 Adob​​e 的服务器上。

如果您使用 DSLR 或无反光镜相机，您的照片将从存储卡上传，如果您使用 iPhone 或其他移动设备拍摄，您也可以将所有文件自动发送到 Lightroom。这意味着您的所有照片始终可以在每台设备上使用，您无需考虑创建备份或为计算机购买更多硬盘。

Lightroom 的云优先设计意味着您可以轻松地与其他人共享照片、创建公共和私人相册以及邀请人们编辑您的图像或创建您编辑内容的混音。这种方法还允许 Adob​​e 创建一个程序，无论您在浏览器中使用移动应用程序、iPad 应用程序、桌面应用程序还是 Lightroom，该程序的功能（几乎）都相同。

此外，Lightroom 中的 Discover 界面的功能有点像社交网络；您可以关注摄影师，查看他们的图像，并逐步浏览他们对公开照片所做的每个单独编辑。这是一个令人难以置信的学习工具，因为您永远不必想知道如何编辑特别令人惊叹的图像 - 相反，您可以一一查看所有编辑。您还可以将这些图像导入到您的库中，并将您自己的图像分享到 Discover。

Lightroom 专业人士

  • 非常适合需要比本机相机应用程序提供更多编辑选项的移动摄影师
  • 基于云的工作流程意味着您可以随时从任何设备访问和编辑所有图像
  • “发现”功能是学习新编辑技术和提高摄影水平的绝佳方式
  • 图像自动标记和关键词，以及智能搜索工具

Lightroom 的缺点

  • 不如 Lightroom Classic 全面
  • 如果您以 RAW 格式拍摄，则很容易达到 1 TB 云存储限制，而且额外的存储非常昂贵。
  • 缺乏智能馆藏和全面的过滤选项使得大型图书馆难以管理

Lightroom 与 Lightroom Classic：易用性

我自 2012 年以来一直使用 Lightroom Classic，它仍然是我摄影工作流程的核心组成部分。我依靠它来进行个人工作、为客户拍摄照片和家庭快照。它可以满足我需要的一切，但也有很多我不需要的。

然而，其广泛的工具和选项也是其致命弱点。 Lightroom Classic 的最大入门障碍（尤其是对于新摄影师来说）是它不太容易使用。其令人眼花缭乱的模块、面板、下拉箭头、对话框和首选项需要数月或数年才能理解，而且许多操作功能强大但不直观。

对于没有使用过这两个程序的摄影师来说，Lightroom 更容易理解，而且它基于云、适合移动设备的特性意味着那些习惯使用 iPhone 或 iPad 完成所有操作的人会感到宾至如归。编辑简单直观，整个应用程序具有更简单的界面，删除了 Lightroom Classic 中提供的一些更复杂的工具，以便创建一组精简但仍然非常强大的选项，让大多数摄影师满意。

Lightroom 与 Lightroom Classic：性能

Lightroom 和 Lightroom Classic 都是功能强大的数字资产管理工具，但 Lightroom Classic 的最大优势之一也是一个重要的弱点。

最新版本的 Lightroom Classic 构建于早于原始 iPhone 的代码库上，这意味着它并未像现代应用程序那样针对速度和效率进行优化。 Adobe 多年来对 Lightroom Classic 进行了极大的改进，新版本当然更好，但即使是像滚动大型照片库或更改图像缩略图大小这样简单的操作也可能会导致问题。应用编辑、转换为 DNG 和导出等正常操作速度非常快，但其他功能（例如面部识别工具）甚至可以让最强大的计算机屈服。

相比之下，Lightroom 绝对可以轻松应对您扔给它的任何内容。滚动浏览数万张照片既快速又流畅，从一张照片翻转到下一张照片几乎是瞬间完成的，编辑工作也非常快捷。

如果您只想从数字资产管理工具中获得纯粹的性能，那么 Lightroom 是首选。但是，如果您喜欢更丰富的编辑和组织工具，但不介意一些性能问题，那么 Lightroom Classic 可能更适合您。

Lightroom 与 Lightroom Classic：照片组织

虽然 Lightroom 在性能和易用性方面具有优势，但当我们考虑照片组织等更复杂的操作时，事情开始变得有趣。在这方面，与 Lightroom Classic 相比，Lightroom 明显贫乏，甚至在其发布几年后，它仍然缺少许多人认为非常基本的组织功能。

Lightroom 使用简单的相册/文件夹结构来组织图像：照片物理存储在文件夹中，但一张图像可以位于多个相册中。图像还可以包含星级和标记（例如“选择”或“拒绝”），并可动态排序以仅显示符合这些特定条件的照片。

但就纯粹的照片组织能力而言，Lightroom Classic 毫无疑问胜出，甚至相差甚远。 Lightroom Classic 具有多种令人眼花缭乱的方法可用于组织、排序、过滤和管理您的图片。您可以使用图库模块中的过滤器栏根据特定条件立即缩小所有镜头的范围，还可以按标记、评级和颜色状态进行搜索。可以创建包含所有匹配（或不匹配）某些规则的图像的智能集合，并且这些图像会不断实时更新。导入图像时，您可以添加元数据、更改文件名并准确指定镜头的放置位置。

因此，如果组织和文件管理是您的首要任务，那么 Lightroom Classic 就是您的最佳选择。

Lightroom 与 Lightroom Classic：编辑功能

当 Adob​​e 于 2017 年发布 Lightroom 时，像我这样的 Lightroom Classic 长期用户对其缺乏的功能感到震惊。它只能执行基本操作，没有太多摄影师工作流程所依赖的遮罩、分级和其他编辑功能。从那时起，Adobe极大地改进了Lightroom的编辑功能，现在它几乎涵盖了大多数摄影师需要的所有操作。

Lightroom 和 Lightroom Classic 提供曝光和颜色调整、色调曲线、颜色分级和镜头校正等基本工具。 Lightroom Classic 在一些方面更深入，例如，它可以让您对色差进行像素级精确控制，而 Lightroom 会自动进行 CA 去除，但这些类型的操作都是异常值。

Lightroom Classic 的人工智能遮罩功能令人印象深刻，它们在 Lightroom 中不可用，但几乎可以肯定它们会在不久的将来添加到 Lightroom 中。当将编辑从一张照片复制到另一张照片或同时同步多张照片的编辑时，Lightroom Classic 还为您提供了更大的控制权。

Lightroom Classic 在编辑功能方面仍然具有优势，但 Lightroom 的工具更易于使用。很难说谁是赢家。这实际上取决于您需要什么，而不是哪个程序做得更多。

如果您进行专业拍摄，您可能会欣赏 Lightroom Classic 提供的更高水平的控制和灵活性，但如果您重视简单性和易用性，那么 Lightroom 可能更适合您。

Lightroom 与 Lightroom Classic：多功能性

当我的孩子上床睡觉后，没有什么比坐在 27 英寸屏幕前、播放音乐并在 Lightroom Classic 中浏览照片更让我享受的了。这是我快乐的地方，我可以长时间沉浸在摄影流的状态中，时间就这样溜走了。 Lightroom Classic 在一个应用程序中提供了我需要的一切，而且它的功能足够丰富，可以处理任何类型的照片拍摄和任何类型的照片。从导入到编辑再到导出，一切都在我需要的地方，并且它的组织方式对我来说有意义。

Lightroom 同样具有多种功能，但方式却完全不同。它对图像管理和编辑过程的每一个微小细节没有相同级别的微观控制，但它确实允许您从任何设备或网络浏览器编辑所有照片。您永远不必考虑图像可能位于何处，或者是否将特定镜头同步到云端。有了 Lightroom，一切都在您需要的时候触手可及。

此外，Lightroom 与 iPad 和 Apple Pencil 的集成非常出色，使用这种方法进行编辑不仅高效，而且充满乐趣和享受。 Lightroom 和 Lightroom Classic 都有不同的用途。两者本质上都不是更好，但其中一种可能更适合您的需求。

Lightroom 与 Lightroom Classic：价格和价值

有一项功能可以让您更轻松地在 Lightroom 与 Lightroom Classic 之间进行选择吗？价格。这两个程序的订阅费相同，均为 9.99 美元/月，这意味着您不必根据哪个更便宜来决定。相反，您只需要看看哪一个适合您的需求。然而，就纯粹的性价比而言，Lightroom Classic 可能还有更多功能。

Adobe 提供 Lightroom Classic 作为其摄影 (20 GB) 计划的组成部分，该计划还包括 Photoshop 的完整版本、20 GB 云存储以及Lightroom 的访问权限。 Lightroom 计划不包括 Photoshop 或 Lightroom Classic，但拥有 1 TB 的云存储空间，足以容纳数十万个 JPEG 文件，但不足以容纳那么多 RAW 文件。

我通常认为摄影计划可以提供更好的价值，但如果您不想或不需要 Photoshop 的编辑工具或 Lightroom Classic 中的组织和管理工具，那么独立的 Lightroom 选项可能是最佳选择。

Lightroom 与 Lightroom Classic：哪个适合您？

虽然 Lightroom 和 Lightroom Classic 都有独特的优点和缺点，但选择并不是哪个程序最好。关键在于哪个计划适合您。

Lightroom Classic 非常适合：

  • 基于桌面的工作流程，其中图像存储在本地而不是云端
  • 希望对编辑的各个方面进行高度控制的专业摄影师
  • 依赖复杂且可定制的照片组织方案的编辑者
  • 想要更专业的工具以及 Photoshop 的爱好者和业余摄影师

Lightroom 非常适合：

  • 基于云的工作流程，其中图像远程存储并可在任何设备或 Web 浏览器上访问
  • 想要比本地相机应用程序提供更多功能的移动摄影师
  • 想要向其他摄影师学习并与全球社区分享他们的图像（和编辑）的用户
  • 重视速度、简单性和易用性的爱好者和业余摄影师

也就是说，智能手机摄影不仅仅是拿起 iPhone 或 Google Pixel、打开相机并将其指向正确的方向。要使用智能手机拍摄精美的照片，您需要考虑各种元素，包括构图、灯光和曝光设置。您还需要考虑特定型号的功能，甚至考虑购买一两个配件。

在以下部分中，我将分享您需要了解的一切，以发挥智能手机的摄影潜力。从选择合适的智能手机拍照设备到了解各种 Android 和 iPhone 模式和设置，我将仔细指导您完成整个过程。我还将与您分享一些简单的技巧，以便您可以开始创建精彩、美丽且令人难忘的属于您自己的手机照片。

现在拿起您的智能手机，准备探索摄影的力量。无论您的技能水平如何，这里总有适合您的东西。让我们开始吧！

使用智能手机进行摄影的主要原因

如果您正在阅读本文，您可能已经知道与数码单反相机和无反光镜等传统相机相比，智能手机具有一些主要优势。但在我们深入研究智能手机摄影的本质之前，我想强调一下手机能够胜过专业相机的几个特殊原因。

首先，始终拥有相机的便携性和便利性是无与伦比的。您的智能手机始终陪伴在您身边，随时准备捕捉那些意想不到的时刻，无论您是在火车上、飞机上、红绿灯处还是在午休时间。

其次，智能手机提供的各种内置功能和模式（例如人像模式、HDR 设置和夜间模式）可以增强普通初学者的图像质量，使其超出使用数码单反相机拍摄的图像。是的，一位经验丰富的摄影师使用昂贵的相机可以通过仔细的方法和同样仔细的编辑来创造类似的效果，但需要时间和大量的努力才能达到这一点。

第三，智能手机可以让你在一个地方拍摄、编辑和分享照片；换句话说，它是一站式摄影商店。想象一下，在一次旅行中，捕捉令人惊叹的日落、编辑图像并在 Facebook 上与朋友和家人分享 - 所有这些都在大约 10 分钟内完成。这种类型的超集成拍摄在数码单反相机上当然是不可能实现的，但却是智能手机摄影的独特优势之一。

最后，与专业相机设备相比，智能手机的成本效益也是一个显着的优势。非智能手机摄影可能是一种昂贵的爱好，尤其是当你考虑到镜头、三脚架和其他配件时。然而，大多数人已经拥有一部可以拍摄精美照片的智能手机——即使您想升级以获得尽可能最好的照片，它仍然不会花费您大量的钱。

如何选择适合摄影的智能手机

您几乎可以使用任何智能手机拍摄精美的照片。但如果您希望捕捉超清晰的图像并获得炫酷的功能，您可能需要考虑具有以照片为中心的功能的 Android 或 iPhone 设备。

选择最佳智能手机摄像头时需要考虑以下几个关键因素：

画面质量

并非所有智能手机相机都能产生同样高质量的照片。分辨率是这里需要考虑的因素之一；百万像素越高通常越好，特别是如果您希望能够在不显着降低质量的情况下裁剪照片。

您还应该寻找更大的传感器，在其他条件相同的情况下，它可以让您在较暗的区域拍摄时获得更清晰、更自然的图像。图像稳定功能也可以派上用场，特别是当您经常在低光照条件下拍摄模糊的照片时。

焦距灵活性

许多智能手机提供多个摄像头。除了无处不在的标准相机之外，您可能会发现带有广角和长焦相机，甚至超广角或超长焦相机的手机。广角相机非常适合拍摄风景，而长焦相机则适合拍摄紧凑的人像和远处的物体。

当您考虑不同的选择时，请考虑最适合您兴趣的相机类型。更多的摄像头通常意味着更大的灵活性，但请务必查看每台摄像头的规格。一台相机的图像质量通常会有所不同，这意味着 48 MP 标准相机不能保证 48 MP 长焦图像。

附加功能和模式

考虑可能对您的摄影有所帮助的其他功能。如果您想在夜间拍摄静止场景（例如从公寓窗户看到的城市景观），夜间模式可以发挥巨大作用。肖像模式可以增加景深效果，而全景模式则非常适合那些宽阔的风景拍摄。

这些附加模式和功能可以将您的摄影提升到一个新的水平，但并非每部智能手机都拥有所有功能。确保您选择的设备能够为您提供捕捉您想要创建的镜头所需的一切。

成本

确定您的预算至关重要，因为智能手机的价格差异很大。您需要考虑您愿意花费的范围，然后寻找该范围内的最佳价值。不要只考虑手机本身的成本。考虑总成本，包括潜在的配件、图像编辑应用程序订阅等。

如果您没有预算购买闪亮的新型号，那么具有强大相机功能的旧型号绝对值得考虑。这一切都是为了在您想要的和您负担得起的之间找到适当的平衡！

智能手机摄影配件：有必要吗？

如果您刚刚开始使用智能手机摄影，那么仅使用智能手机进行拍摄就可以了。然而，一旦您更加熟悉手机摄像头，特别是如果您想专注于某些摄影类型，您可能需要考虑购买一两个配件。

现在，我并不是说你应该冲出去购买市场上的所有小玩意和小玩意。离得很远。相反，首先要了解您的兴趣。您喜欢广阔的风景还是特写花卉照片吗？根据您的回答，您的智能手机设置应该看起来完全不同。

随着您变得更加自信并且您的技能开始提高，您可以开始构建您的工具包。当您这样做时，以下是一些值得考虑的事项：

三脚架

稳定性是摄影的关键，特别是对于长时间曝光的拍摄，这就是三脚架派上用场的地方。如果您正在拍摄一个场景并且想要展示运动（例如流经山谷的溪流），那么三脚架可以让您的智能手机相机在拍摄几秒钟的照片时保持静止。

此外，当您希望将多个镜头融合在一起时，三脚架可以实现一致的取景；如果你想创造令人惊叹的延时摄影，这是关键。

寻找便携式和可调节的选项。有些三脚架甚至配备了蓝牙遥控器，让您无需触摸手机即可远距离拍照。您只需将智能手机安装在三脚架上，退后一步，然后使用遥控器即可捕捉完美瞬间，而无需担心相机抖动。

夹式镜片

也许您想要捕捉超广角风景、详细的微距图像或惊慌主体的照片？如果是这种情况，夹式镜头可以帮助您增强智能手机的功能。它们有多种类型，包括广角、鱼眼、微距和长焦，它们当然可以在拍摄时为您提供额外的焦距灵活性。

不过，在购买夹式镜头之前，请确保与您的智能手机型号兼容。 Additionally, the quality varies wildly from lens to lens – this is something that I have plenty of experience with! – so it's wise to read reviews and maybe even test out a few options before investing.

Portable lighting

While professional photographers often love to use studio lighting, even serious iPhone and Android photographers tend to shy away from most forms of artificial light. It cuts down on portability, and it generally doesn't look that great.

That said, portable lighting solutions are sometimes useful for smartphone portrait and smartphone product photography; in particular, they can significantly improve lighting for indoor or low-light shots.

If you need an artificial light boost, consider LED ring lights or small portable LED panels. Some even come with adjustable color temperature for creative control. These tools can help you manage shadows and highlights in a way that helps you craft the mood you want to create, and they're designed to be ultra-lightweight and compact.

15 tips to level up your smartphone photos

Now let's take a look at the tips, tricks, and techniques you can use to capture beautiful photos using your smartphone, starting with:

1. Clean your lens

This tip is extremely basic, but you will be amazed by the dirt and grime that accumulate on your smartphone lens. (When I reach for my phone, I often find lots of smudges and dirt caused by my kids, my pockets, the environment, and more.)

So do yourself a favor and get in the habit of quickly wiping your phone lens before beginning a photoshoot. It'll make your photos look so much sharper!

Note that you'll want to pay especially close attention to your smartphone camera lens during bad weather; if you're photographing in the rain, for instance, a single drop of water can turn the whole shot blurry. Make sure you wipe that lens clean at least every few minutes!

2. Tap the screen to set focus

Typically, when you point your smartphone at a subject, the camera will guess what you want to photograph. For instance, if it recognizes faces, it'll focus on the faces; if it recognizes a person, it'll focus on the person.

This method of autofocusing can work well, especially if you're photographing a clear scene with an obvious main subject. But when the scene is more complex – you're photographing a bird surrounded by trees, for example – your smartphone may get the focusing wrong, and the shot will turn out blurry.

So what do you do?

Instead of letting your smartphone's algorithms determine your point of focus, simply tap on your subject, and then – voila! – you'll get a sharp result.

Note: If you want extremely fine control over your smartphone's focusing – such as when you're doing close-up photography – there are a variety of camera apps that allow you to focus manually so that you can rack the plane of focus back and forth until you get the results you're after!

3. Don't use flash

Your smartphone camera has a flash, but it really, really sucks! Sorry – there simply isn't a way to sugarcoat it: The flash on your phone camera is not flattering for photos, whether you're shooting in the daytime, late at night, landscapes , flowers, or portraits.

So whenever you're shooting, keep that flash off . Instead, use natural light for great results. For instance, shoot in the early morning or the late evening to get beautiful golden lighting , or work on cloudy days for soft, evenly lit images.

And if you desperately need extra light, invest in lighting accessories designed for smartphones, such as an LED ring light.

4. Discreetly take photos by pressing the volume buttons

Sometimes, the perfect shot requires a touch of subtlety – such as when you notice a beautiful scene while out walking, or if you're watching your kids do something especially cute. In such instances, using the volume button to take photos is a great way to capture the image without disturbing the subjects or making them feel self-conscious.

How does this work? Some smartphones automatically set the volume buttons as an alternative shutter control, while others don't default to this option but do let you set it up on your own (this process is simple and usually involves togging an item in the camera settings). Then, with your smartphone set, you can discreetly raise your camera and nudge a volume button upward or downward.

Remember, the key here is to use this technique with care and ethics. The goal isn't to make your subjects feel uncomfortable!

5. Manually set the image brightness

Did you know that you can set image brightness (ie, image exposure ) manually?

It's true, and you can use this function to control the level of detail that will appear in the final photo.

The details depend on your specific smartphone model, but try tapping on the screen, then look for some sort of exposure symbol (such as a sun). Swipe up (or drag the corresponding slider) to brighten the exposure, and swipe down (or drag the corresponding slider) to darken it.

6. Make sure your smartphone's HDR function is on

HDR is a handy feature found in most smartphones today, and you might be surprised to learn how much it can enhance your photos. It stands for high dynamic range , and its primary purpose is to bring out the details in the shadows and highlights. It works by taking multiple shots at different exposures and then merging them together to create a balanced image.

Most modern phones offer some sort of HDR option, which can often be toggled on and off in your phone's settings. (It's usually tucked away in the camera app settings.)

What's important is that you make sure HDR is active when you're photographing scenes with significant contrast between bright and dark areas. It's especially useful for landscapes where the sky is bright but the land is shrouded in shadow, or for subjects that are lit from behind. As long as it's enabled, HDR will work its magic to even out those contrasts and make the image look more like how your eyes see it.

On the other hand, there are times when you might want to turn HDR off, such as when you're aiming for a more dramatic or moody effect. It's good to know how to control the feature so you can make a choice that fits your creative vision.

7. Compose your photos creatively

Composition refers to the arrangement of elements in the frame. If you want to capture stunning photos, you must carefully position people and objects in a pleasing way.

A few quick pieces of advice:

  • Avoid placing your subject smack-dab in the center of the frame
  • Symmetry often looks good
  • Try to include a natural frame around your subject, like a window, a doorway, or an arch

If you want especially beautiful compositions, I'd recommend using the rule of thirds , which encourages you to position key elements a third of the way into the image. See how the chairs are positioned around the bottom-third portion of the frame:

Note that you don't have to use the rule of thirds – it's not really a rule, just a guideline – but it helps create compositions that are well-balanced and dynamic at the same time.

8. Try the rule of odds

Another tip for great smartphone composition is the rule of odds , which encourages you to group your subjects in odd-numbered collections.

(For some reason, odd-numbered collections just tend to look good!)

So if you were photographing a group of people, you'd want to include three, five, or seven people in a cluster – not two or four. And if you were photographing a group of forks, you'd want to include three, five, seven, or nine. Make sense?

As with the rule of thirds, the rule of odds isn't actually a rule. It's a suggestion – but a good one, so I do recommend you follow it whenever possible!

9. Test out your smartphone's photography modes

Your smartphone likely comes with several photography modes, each offering a different way to create your images.

Portrait mode, for instance, will blur the background and put focus on the subject. This is great for individual or couple photos and can give a professional touch, similar to what you could achieve with a high-end camera.

Night mode is another powerful feature. If you've ever tried to take a photo in low light, you know how difficult it can be, but Night mode takes several images and blends them together for a clear and bright shot.

And then there's Panorama. Want to capture a breathtaking landscape? Panorama mode lets you take a series of photos and stitch them together into one wide image.

You don't need to be a technical whiz to use these modes. Just find them in your camera app, select the one that fits your scene, and shoot. Over time, you'll get a feel for when to use each mode, but experimenting is the best way to learn!

So don't hesitate to try these modes and see what works best for you. The more you play with them, the more you'll understand what they can do. That's the first step in becoming a more skilled and confident smartphone photographer.

10. Straighten the horizon

A common beginner smartphone photography mistake is a crooked horizon. After all, it's so easy to accidentally tilt your phone when shooting!

Unfortunately, crooked horizons are a major problem, and unless you know how to handle them (either in the field or in post-processing), you'll be stuck with a set of bad photos.

Fortunately, dealing with crooked horizons isn't difficult. Simply take a moment to turn on your camera grid; this will display a set of lines across the screen, which you can then use to level your horizons in the field.

You can also handle crooked horizons in post-processing. Most editing apps include some sort of straightening option, though you will lose pixels in the process, so it's always best to get it right in the field!

11. Use leading lines

Leading lines are lines that lead the viewer into the frame and draw attention to the main subject. And these lines, if used correctly, are insanely powerful.

When you're shooting with your smartphone, look around for roads, buildings, or even furniture that can help lead the eye to the subject. Technically, a leading line can be pretty much anything, from outstretched arms and tree branches to road signs and buildings, so even if you can't see any obvious lines, I encourage you to keep looking!

Once you find a leading line, adjust your position so that it points to the main subject. Your composition will instantly improve! Here, I used the row of chairs to direct the viewer toward the building in the background:

12. Photograph in natural light

Earlier in the article, I mentioned the value of natural light, but it's so important that it deserves its own section. You see, there is something so pure and clean about photographing in natural light. It looks great, it produces beautiful photos, and it's always available.

I love morning and evening light because of its golden hues and soft, flattering effect. Overcast light is nice, too. And even high-contrast light produced by the harsh sun can look amazing (especially in black and white).

If you shoot in heavy shade or at night, you can still use natural light, but you'll need to use a tripod to prevent image blur. (Fortunately, there are plenty of high-quality yet relatively cheap smartphone tripods to choose from!)

13. Try not to zoom

Unless your smartphone offers a proper telephoto camera, I recommend you do as little zooming as possible.

You see, most zoom functions use digital zoom, which simply crops the image to magnify the subject. In other words, it doesn't actually get you closer to the subject; instead, it just removes pixels. Recently, smartphone manufacturers have developed algorithms that allow for slightly better results when zooming digitally, but it's still always better to get close to your subjects instead of relying on your device's digital zoom capabilities.

If you own a smartphone with a zoom capability, and you're not sure whether the images are simply cropped or whether the device boasts a genuine telephoto lens, go ahead and read the specifications sheet (you can find this on the manufacturer's website). In general, this should clear things up, and you can determine the best approach for photographing distant subjects.

14. Consider using a sophisticated camera app

I know that you might be comfortable with the built-in camera app on your smartphone. But as you grow in your photography skills, you'll find that more sophisticated camera apps can provide you with greater control and creativity.

Many advanced camera apps offer manual controls. Imagine being able to adjust the shutter speed, ISO, and white balance, just like professional photographers do with their DSLRs. And as I mentioned in a previous tip, some of these apps let you focus manually to pinpoint exactly where you want the sharpest details in your image.

Some apps also allow for a more artistic shooting process. They'll apply filters to your camera feed in advance so you can see the world in high-contrast black and white, intense grunge, monochromatic blue, and much more. If you're in a creative rut, trying such an app can certainly help you out.

Note that camera apps like Adobe Lightroom Mobile and ProCam offer significant manual capabilities and are generally user-friendly, so don't be afraid to experiment with them and see what you think.

15. Process your images using an editing app

The work doesn't stop once you've captured a nice photo – because with a little post-processing, you can turn a good image into a great one. And the best part? You don't need to be a Photoshop wizard to do it. Most smartphones come with a range of easy-to-use editing apps that can help you enhance your pictures.

I'd recommend starting with the basics: Crop your photo to improve the composition, then adjust brightness and contrast to make the image pop. You might also tweak the white balance or add a bit of sharpening. Don't be afraid to play around with these settings. Often, a little tweak here and there can make a world of difference.

Many of these apps also offer filters and presets. These are ready-made settings that apply a particular look to your image with just a single tap. They can be a fun way to explore different styles, but be sure to use them judiciously. Sometimes, less is more.

If you want to dive a little deeper, some apps allow more advanced editing like layering and blending. You might find these options a bit more challenging if you're new to editing, but don't be discouraged. There are plenty of tutorials online that can guide you through the process.

What's vital here is to maintain the quality of your image during editing. If the app doesn't offer non-destructive processing, always work on a copy of the photo rather than the original file, and be cautious not to over-edit. Subtlety often works best.

Editing isn't about changing what you captured; it's about enhancing it. Think of it as the final touch that brings your photo to life. And most importantly, have fun with it! Experimenting with different techniques can be an enjoyable and rewarding part of the photographic process.

How to take amazing smartphone photos: final words

With a bit of practice, you can capture amazing smartphone photos of landscapes, people, and so much more – even if you're an absolute beginner.

Keep in mind that photographing with a smartphone should be simple . At the same time, an iPhone or Android camera is a genuinely powerful tool to explore the world around you, capture memories, and express your artistic vision. There's no right or wrong approach, so feel free to experiment and find what works best for you.

I encourage you to pick up your phone and start exploring the possibilities. You might be surprised at what you can create. And remember, the best camera is the one you have with you!

Horses are not just beautiful and intelligent creatures; they can be the subjects of some truly breathtaking photographs. And horse photography – which is all about capturing the grace and majesty of these animals – is intensely rewarding.

Yet photographing horses can present certain challenges. Horses are free-spirited, plus they can be easily spooked. Add to that the technical expertise required to photograph a horse in action, such as racing or jumping, and you might start to feel more than a bit overwhelmed.

But don't worry! Even a beginner can learn to take great horse photos; they just need an experienced guide. I've done plenty of horse photography, and I've also spent plenty of time learning from trainers and owners. In this article, I share it all: how to capture beautiful horse portraits, how to create stunning horse race photos, and even how to effectively photograph events like show jumping.

Ready to create some gorgeous horse images? Let's dive right in!

1. Be careful

Approaching a horse with a camera is not always straightforward. While some horses may be exceedingly gentle, others can be unpredictable or even aggressive. A single kick from a horse can cause serious injuries, so caution is essential.

Never stand behind a horse or catch them by surprise. Sudden movements or even wearing bright colors can startle them. It's essential to be aware of the horse's presence and ensure they know where you are.

Before diving into the photography session, have a chat with the owner or handler about the horse's personality. Is the horse flighty or bitey? Have they ever seen a camera before? Understanding these aspects can help you approach with caution.

Flash photography is generally a no-no around horses unless you're sure they are used to it. A flash could endanger not just you but also the horse and the handler. I advise avoiding it as much as possible.

2. Learn the horse's language

Horses communicate through their ears, leg stance, and head movements. This language is understood by horse owners and trainers, but it might be new to you. Spend some time researching horse body language before your first shoot. You'll want to understand how the horse is feeling to predict their behavior and avoid danger.

Horse owners often prefer certain positioning of ears, legs, and heads. For example, pinned-back ears signify an unhappy horse, while relaxed, forward ears can mean the horse is content. Understanding this language will not only keep you safe but also ensure you capture shots that the owners will love.

If you're familiar with this equine language, you'll have a better sense of what the owners want, and your photo shoot will be more successful. So invest a little time in this unique aspect of horse photography; it's well worth it!

3. Start with an introduction

Photographing horses isn't about jumping right in with your camera. It requires a delicate approach. When you first meet the horse, it's essential to create a calm environment.

Let the handler introduce you if the horse is calm enough. Allow the horse to approach you, sniff the camera, and become familiar with your presence. Talk softly and move slowly; a gentle pat might be welcomed if the handler deems it appropriate.

Are you unsure how the horse will react to the sounds of your camera? Organize a few test shots with the handler. Ensuring that everyone is in a safe position during these test shots is vital. If the horse reacts negatively, a sudden buck or kick can be dangerous.

If your camera has a silent shooting mode, this is a great time to use it. But remember, “silent” doesn't always mean entirely noiseless. Test it out to gauge the horse's reaction.

4. Choose the right lens for horse photography

Selecting the right lens is a critical decision in horse photography. It can be influenced by various factors, including the horse's temperament and the type of shots you're aiming for.

If you're doing a portrait session and the horse is comfortable with you getting close, a wide-to-standard zoom lens, like a 24-70mm with a maximum aperture of f/2.8, can be a great choice. With it, you can capture wide-angle shots or zoom in for tighter images.

A 50mm or 85mm prime lens is also a fantastic option. These lenses often offer quality at an affordable price, with a wide aperture like f/1.8 for beautiful background blur .

When photographing from the sidelines or with a skittish horse, a longer telephoto lens is a must. A 70-200mm lens will allow you to capture detailed images from a distance.

Sometimes, having a good telephoto zoom handy, even with a more approachable horse, can enhance your shots. It allows you to get those close-up details without invading the horse's personal space.

5. Dial in the right horse photography settings

Setting your camera correctly is fundamental. Using Auto mode won't do justice to these magnificent creatures; instead, you'll likely end up with blurry shots.

Shutter Priority , Aperture Priority , or Manual mode are your friends here. A fast shutter speed is essential – a minimum of 1/250s for general horse photography. If the horse is moving quickly, even faster speeds like 1/500s or 1/1000s are necessary.

Don't be afraid to boost your ISO if you need to ensure a good exposure. Modern cameras handle high ISO quite well, but test your camera to know your limits.

A wide aperture, such as f/2.8 or f/4, can be valuable, especially in low-light conditions. But remember, a wider aperture narrows the window of sharpness. You'll need to focus with precision, making sure the horse's eyes and head are in sharp focus.

Getting the settings right will allow you to capture the horse's grace and energy, adding depth and emotion to your photographs. It's a combination of understanding the horse's behavior and using your camera's capabilities to their fullest potential. It's not about having the most expensive gear, but about knowing how to use what you have to create stunning images.

6. Photograph the tender moments

Connecting with a horse is a magical experience. Capturing that connection between horse and rider in your lens? Even more so. Every horse owner has a bond with their companion that is unique, personal, and full of emotion. As a photographer, your mission is to capture that bond, that shared love, in a way that transcends the physical frame.

Take a moment to observe. Notice the horse and its owner, their interactions, their unspoken communication. Look for the soft moments, the shared glances, the loving gestures. It's in these fleeting moments that the true essence of their relationship lies. Patience is key here, and waiting for these tender moments can often reward you with the most touching and powerful images.

An integral part of this process involves integrating the rider into your photoshoot. It's essential for you to keep them engaged, keep them relaxed. Encourage them to interact with their horse naturally, as they would when no one is watching. These candid shots often result in the most authentic images, brimming with raw emotions and moments of connection. Remember, horse lovers are often just as excited to be part of the shoot as they are to have their equine companions photographed.

7. Don't forget about the details

Horse photography is not just about the whole animal, but also about capturing the individual details that make each horse unique. These can range from the gleaming shine in their coat to the distinct patterns of their markings, the flowing mane, the softness in their eyes, and so much more.

I always find it useful to have a chat with the owner before I start clicking away. Get to know the horse through their eyes, understand what makes their horse special to them. They might have a fondness for certain features – the curve of the horse's neck, the unique color of their eyes, the way their mane catches the light. Your job as a photographer is to capture these personal favorites in the best light possible.

Use your lens wisely for these detail shots. A telephoto lens works great if you want to maintain a safe distance, especially if the horse is a little skittish. However, with a calm and friendly horse, feel free to move closer and use a standard lens. Experiment with varying your aperture to create a range of effects, from an overall sharp image to a focused shot with a beautifully blurred background.

8. Take your time

A crucial tip for successful horse photography, which I can't emphasize enough, is to take your time. Spend a day, if possible, with the horse and the owner. Get to know them, understand their dynamics, build a rapport. Patience and understanding go a long way in establishing trust, which in turn helps capture the best possible images.

Observe the horse's habits, their likes and dislikes. Maybe they love a particular spot in the paddock, or they jump around gleefully after a good run. Keeping these nuances in mind will help you anticipate their actions and be prepared for spontaneous shots.

Slowing down also allows you to notice the small but significant details of the environment around you – interesting backgrounds, shifting light patterns, shadows, and reflections. All these elements can add depth and context to your photographs, turning a good picture into a great one.

Don't rush the process. Horse photography, like all good things in life, takes time. It requires patience, practice, and a keen eye for detail. But rest assured, the results will be worth your effort.

9. Use similar techniques to photograph equine events

Photographing equine events like show jumping has its own challenges, but many of the principles remain the same. Finding a safe spot is crucial, and one where the horse can see you from a distance. Always stay put and never move towards the horse and rider, and remember, using flash is a big no-no. Checking with any officials before you start is also a smart move.

To capture both horse and rider in mid-jump – a favorite of horse riders – you'll likely need a shutter speed around 1/650s to 1/800s. By setting your camera to continuous release (burst) mode , you can press the shutter just as the horse lifts off, increasing your chances of getting the perfect shot.

Focusing can be tricky, so you'll need to be extra attentive. Prefocusing in advance where you know the horse will be is an option, but I find using your camera's AF tracking to follow the horse generally better. It lets you shoot a variety of images as the horse moves in different directions, giving you a range of dynamic shots to choose from.

10. Work fast for horse race photography

Horse racing is a thrilling sport, and capturing it in a photograph requires a special touch. Horses at top speeds are incredibly fast, so I'd recommend the fastest shutter speed the light will allow. Use your camera's continuous shooting mode, and don't hesitate to take hundreds of shots. Among the failures and near-duplicates, you'll find those magical moments that make it all worth it.

Getting close to the finish line at smaller race meets can make for breathtaking photos, but you'll need permission. Assure the officials that you don't use flash and that you understand how easily horses can be spooked. Your diligence can grant you access to some unique vantage points.

Here's a pro tip: try panning shots during the races. It captures the sense of movement and speed, giving your photos an artistic flair. Lower your shutter speed to around 1/30s and move your camera along with your subject as you fire the shutter. If done right, you'll end up with a sharp horse and rider against a stunning blur of motion in the background.

This technique might take a few tries to master, but the resulting images can be truly spectacular. Combining both standard and panning shots during horse races can provide you with an exciting and varied portfolio of images, each illustrating a different aspect of the race!

Horse photography tips: final words

From understanding a horse's personality and body language to choosing the right lens and settings, we've explored essential tips and techniques so you can capture beautiful images of horses.

Remember to approach each photo session with care and patience; with some perseverance, you'll capture plenty of horse photos you can be proud of – whether it's a tender moment between rider and horse, or the thrilling speed of a race.

Now it's your turn to grab a camera and explore the world of equine photography. Happy shooting, and have fun!

但捕捉美丽的夜间街头摄影可能很困难。您必须选择正确的设置、应对相机抖动、找到完美的拍摄对象等等。足以让任何人头疼！

幸运的是，我多年来一直从事夜间街头摄影。随着时间的推移，我学到了很多技巧、技​​巧和智慧，可以提高任何人的夜间街头拍摄能力。我测试了不同的设置，确定了如何处理夜间照明，并且学会了如何保持安全。

因此，要了解我的顶级街头夜间摄影技巧 - 并学习如何即使在黑暗中也能捕捉华丽的图像 - 请继续阅读！

什么是夜间街拍？

夜间街头摄影是指在黄昏后拍摄日常风景（通常以城市中的人物为主题）的做法。

夜间拍摄面临着各种各样的挑战，但街头摄影师在夜间拍摄已有大约一个世纪的历史。现代主义摄影师先锋 Andre Kertesz 在 1920 年代在巴黎拍摄了美丽的夜间街拍，他启发了另一位技艺高超的巴黎摄影师 Brassai，在 1930 年代创作了令人惊叹的夜间街拍。

夜间街头摄影师无法享受到强烈的阳光，因此他们被迫使用各种不同的方法来补偿。其中包括基于技术和设备的技术，例如长快门速度、高 ISO、闪光灯和快速镜头，以及视觉技术，例如包含模糊和颗粒的调整美学。

夜间街头摄影往往具有奇妙的氛围，事实证明它在 21 世纪非常流行，特别是随着低光相机技术的不断改进。

夜间拍摄街道的优点和缺点

夜间街头摄影有几个主要好处 - 换句话说，它受欢迎是有原因的！

首先，街道在晚上往往比较空旷，让你可以毫无困难地隔离一两个拍摄对象——这可以拍出更强大的简约镜头。

在夜间用路灯拍摄也会给图像增添不同的情绪，给人一种神秘、怀旧、戏剧甚至恐怖的感觉，具体取决于你的拍摄方式。

崭露头角的街头摄影师——甚至更有成就的摄影师——在拍摄陌生人时有时会因恐惧或不适而挣扎。然而，晚上工作会给人一种距离感和匿名感，从而减少焦虑。

当然，夜间街头摄影面临着一些重大挑战。相机依靠光线来捕捉清晰、曝光良好的图像，尤其是夜间——您无疑已经知道了！ – 没有提供太多的光线。为了解决这个问题，真正掌握相机技术非常重要。否则，您最终会得到模糊、颗粒状或黑暗（或三者组合）的图像。

虽然我在文章末尾更深入地讨论了这一点，但在某些区域夜间拍摄确实很危险。显然，这取决于位置，也取决于您采取的方法。下面，我提供了在夜间采取适当安全预防措施的提示，但记住这一点确实很重要，这样您就不会毫无准备。

夜间街拍照片的最佳相机设置

捕捉清晰的街头照片主要取决于快门速度，所以这就是我想开始的地方。为了定格白天的运动，我更喜欢使用 1/320 秒的快门速度（以 1/160 秒作为我的下限）。但到了晚上，情况就会发生变化。在最亮的区域（路灯或汽车前灯照明），您可以轻松地以 1/250 秒的速度进行拍摄，但大多数时候，您需要使用 1/160 秒到 1/60 秒之间的快门速度。否则，您将被迫将 ISO 提高到荒谬的高度，并且您将面临因噪点而毁掉图像的风险。

请注意，当快门速度设置为 1/60 秒时，您需要稳定的双手。 （具有图像稳定功能的镜头或相机也可以提供帮助！）事实上，要以 1/60 秒的速度手持拍摄，您需要完全停止自己的运动。幸运的是，通过一些练习，这是可以做到的。

至于光圈设置：光圈越宽，快门速度就越快（或者 ISO 可以降低得越低）。在夜间较亮的区域可以使用 f/4 进行拍摄，但如果您可以使用 f/2.8、f/2 甚至 f/1.8 进行拍摄，那么拍摄会轻松很多。换句话说，夜间街头摄影的光圈越大越好。

最后，您需要将 ISO 提高到 1600、3200 甚至 6400。使用现代数码相机，您可以在高 ISO 下拍摄并拍摄出不错的图像，但最好保持 ISO 尽可能低，否则您将无法在夜间拍摄出曝光良好的照片。 （我个人使用 ISO 3200 进行拍摄，有时在特别黑暗的区域或拍摄快速移动的物体时，我会使用 ISO 6400。）

您应该使用什么相机模式？如果您在各种不同的照明场景（即进出路灯）中进行快节奏拍摄，光圈优先可以很好地发挥作用 - 只需将相机设置为最大光圈和最高可容忍 ISO，然后让它为您选择快门速度。 （如果快门速度低于 1/60 秒，那么您要么需要接受一些模糊，要么进一步提高 ISO。）

至于对焦方法：通常情况下，区域对焦是街头摄影的好方法，但在夜间使用超广角光圈时，您最终会丢失很多图像。如果您可以提前预测拍摄，您可以尝试使用手动对焦在某个区域进行预对焦，但使用连续自动对焦和相机的跟踪模式之一可能是更好的选择，具体取决于相机的功能。 （如果您不确定什么最有效，请尝试做一些实验！）

夜间街头摄影的必备装备

最好的夜间街头摄影装备与白天街头摄影装备大致相似，因为您希望您的设备轻便、紧凑且不引人注目。也就是说，在为夜间探险购买新设备时需要记住以下几点：

选择具有良好高 ISO 功能的相机

由于您经常会在 ISO 3200、ISO 6400 甚至更高的感光度下进行拍摄，因此使用不会因噪音爆炸而破坏您的照片的街头摄影相机至关重要。考虑投资紧凑型全画幅相机或一流的 APS-C 型号，并尽量将百万像素数保持在较低水平，因为与普通相机相比，超高 MP 相机在高 ISO 下拍摄时实际上往往表现更差MP 较低的兄弟姐妹（假设该技术来自同一代）。

低光对焦功能也非常方便——许多相机很难在黑暗中对焦，而其他相机则在这方面表现出色。如果您的相机无法在近乎黑暗的情况下对焦，这并不是绝对的问题——您可以手动对焦或在路灯下拍摄——但这肯定会限制您的灵活性。

选择最大光圈较宽的镜头

正如我上面提到的，您需要确保选择一款紧凑型镜头来拍摄夜间街道。但是，虽然大多数白天街头摄影都是在 f/8 左右的光圈下拍摄的，但夜间则是完全不同的情况。您需要将镜头的光圈扩大到最大，这意味着镜头提供的最大光圈越宽越好。

因此，我建议使用最大光圈至少为 f/2.8 的镜头（假设模型仍然相对紧凑，f/1.8 或 f/1.4 可能更好）。

它还可以帮助您获得比您可能倾向于使用的更宽的定焦镜头，例如 35 毫米、28 毫米，或者（如果您对更独特的外观感兴趣）24 毫米。广角镜头不易出现相机抖动，而且在夜间也更容易使用，因为黑暗和缺乏活动会减少整个场景中的干扰。

当然，您仍然可以使用标准 50 毫米镜头进行夜间街头摄影 - 例如，50 毫米 f/1.8 几乎适合所有街头摄影场景 - 但如果您有机会使用广角镜头，我建议您在至少测试一下！

夜间街头摄影的 10 个技巧

现在您已经了解了夜间拍摄街道的最佳设置和设备，让我们来看看一些针对初学者和高级街头拍摄者的提示，以提高您的拍摄效果。

1.寻找光源

始终注意场景中的主要光源。无论您在何时何地拍摄，这一点都是如此，但在夜间变得更加重要。因此，与其寻找拍摄对象，不如从寻找美丽的光源或照明良好的区域开始，然后等待事情发生。

请注意，夜间街头摄影照明可以是任何东西：汽车头灯、路灯、霓虹灯、窗户照明，甚至智能手机灯。只需寻找明显的照明，然后仔细注意这些光源如何照射到潜在的拍摄对象即可。调整角度，直到获得您想要的灯光效果，然后拍摄！

2. 多拍几张照片

有时，街头摄影师喜欢使用更谨慎的方法，只拍摄每个主题的几张图像。这在白天效果很好，特别是如果您可以自信地确定焦点和曝光，但在晚上，这会导致许多失败的图像。

因此，当您晚上外出时，不要只为每个主题或场景拍摄一两张图像，而是要稍微推动一下。不要害怕拍摄同一主题的 5-10 张照片，如果您愿意稍后对所有照片进行排序，您甚至可以考虑使用相机的连拍模式在几秒钟内拍摄数十张照片。

这里的想法只是最大化你成功的机会。你拍摄的次数越多，你就越有可能抓住拍摄对象移动得足够慢以保持锐利的那一刻，即使是在 1/60 秒的情况下也是如此——而且即使在极薄的景深下，你也更有可能抓住焦点。场地。

3.拍摄夜生活

城市的某些地方——比如商业区——在晚上可能会空无一人。它们会带来糟糕的夜间街头摄影体验。然而，其他地区在日落后会变得更加繁忙，并且会提供大量机会。

所以寻找夜生活并拍摄吧！您可以考虑在互联网上搜索您所在地区的酒吧和俱乐部，然后确保在夜晚开始时前往。或者，如果您想要更正式的主题，可以去一些高档餐厅附近散步，看看能找到什么！

并且不要觉得您仅限于在俱乐部和餐馆外的街道上拍摄人们。您可以通过窗户拍摄来捕捉各种令人惊叹的效果（此外，如果您对拍摄人物感到有点紧张，窗户可以充当障碍并减少您的焦虑）。

4. 交替靠近和后退

我非常支持罗伯特·卡帕的建议：“如果你的照片不够好，那是因为你离得不够近。”然而，我经常在晚上违反这个规则。

你看，虽然我确实尝试接近我的许多主题 - 我鼓励你也这样做 - 我也尝试创作其中主题是整个场景的小方面的构图。晚上，背景可能比白天漂亮得多，因此让人物成为场景中的次要元素而不是主要焦点通常是值得的。

这种方法具有技术优势：当拍摄对象位于远处时，您无需使用较快的快门速度来捕捉他们的动作。附近的拍摄对象可以以 1/125 秒或更快的速度冻结；通常可以用 1/60 秒拍摄远处的物体，即使它在移动，也能拍出清晰的效果。

5. 尝试使用三脚架以获得创意效果

在进行街头夜间摄影时，通常最好手持。毕竟，你永远不知道会发生什么有趣的事情，并且你希望能够快速做出反应。

也就是说，带上三脚架会很有用，特别是如果您有兴趣拍摄一些长时间曝光的街头摄影。

这里的想法是找到一个繁忙的区域，将相机安装在三脚架上，然后使用慢快门速度捕捉运动中的人物。您需要尝试不同的快门速度（1/8 秒是一个很好的起点），并且您需要拍摄大量照片，但最终会得到一些华丽的运动模糊效果：

我花了很长时间才捕捉到上面显示的图像；我希望人物遍布整个场景，我还想要一个有趣的前景主题（最后，我对街上的女人和看着她的男人的姿势感到满意）。

6.尝试使用闪光灯

一些街头摄影师喜欢使用闪光灯，而另一些则讨厌它。是否决定在夜间尝试闪光灯取决于您；一方面，它会提供额外的照明，因此您可以使用更快的快门速度、更窄的光圈和更低的 ISO。另一方面，它会给人一种非常强烈的车头灯下的鹿的感觉，而且它可能会导致对抗（人们不喜欢被闪光，尤其是在黑暗中！）。

就我个人而言，我更喜欢在自然光的限制下工作，而且在黑暗环境中闪烁的陌生人也会让我感到不舒服。但如果您有足够的信心使用闪光灯拍摄，那么请务必尝试一下，看看您的想法。如果做得好的话，它可以呈现出美妙的外观。

请注意，您可以让闪光灯完成照亮场景的所有工作（以便前景区域变亮而背景完全黑暗）。但您也可以将相机设置为稍微曝光不足的场景，然后使用闪光灯为前景中的主要拍摄对象添加一些补光。

7. 增加曝光时要小心

当使用高 ISO 拍摄时，确定曝光很重要；这样，您在编辑时就不会被迫增加亮度，否则会夸大令人不快的噪点效果。

话虽这么说，您偶尔会遇到意外拍摄曝光不足的情况。当这种情况发生时，你别无选择，只能在编辑时提高曝光度。只要确保你小心翼翼地做就可以了。

这是我的建议：首先，忽略噪音并获得曝光并看起来正确。如果您必须大幅提高曝光度，噪点将会很严重，因此您需要应用一些降噪措施。

有很多优秀的降噪程序，但我喜欢 Lightroom 内置的降噪功能。如果应用降噪算法后噪点仍然很严重，请尝试将图像带入Photoshop中添加非常轻微的高斯模糊。

那时，我经常使用 Lightroom 的颗粒设置将纹理添加回照片中。结果看起来比极端的数字噪声更悦目，并且它可以隐藏曝光不足图像的一些技术缺陷。照片看起来不会非常清晰，但仍然很漂亮。

8. 不要害怕模糊和不完美

大多数街头摄影师的目标是让他们的照片尽可能清晰。清晰度当然不是坏事 - 但要知道，即使照片不是非常清晰，它仍然可以看起来很棒。

您会发现，在夜间拍摄时，您不需要完美地冻结运动即可获得令人惊叹的结果。就我个人而言，我对白天图像的要求高于夜间图像的标准。我的白天图像需要看起来清晰，而我的夜间照片只需要有趣且看起来不错，即使有些地方有点模糊。

此外，在 1/60 秒到 1/30 秒左右的快门速度下，手持拍摄会很有趣。你的拍摄对象会显得有些尖锐，但也会有一些运动。这是为您的作品增添活力的好方法。

9.让你的夜间街拍照片看起来很暗

在我看来，夜景拍摄应该看起来像在晚上拍摄的。它们应该是黑暗的，有很深的阴影和难以看到的区域。当您查看夜间图像的直方图时，它应该向最左侧倾斜，尤其是相对于白天图像而言。

但是，当您将相机对准夜间的街景时，照片通常会曝光过度。生成的文件看起来很明亮，您将能够看到大量细节，但场景感觉不真实。 （您最终还会看到路灯和商店橱窗被炸毁。）在这种情况下，您需要稍微降低相机的曝光补偿，或者 – 如果您在手动模式下拍摄 – 提高快门速度，缩小光圈，或扩大 ISO。

我确实认为明亮的夜间图像看起来不错。但黑暗、逼真的夜间图像通常更好，因此请仔细监视直方图，不要害怕根据需要放弃曝光补偿。

10.小心

根据您居住的地方，晚上携带相机外出并不总是最安全的主意。轻装出行，尽量减少携带的装备，并小心出行。确保注意周围环境，如果您开始感到不舒服，请转向另一个方向。

如果您不确定晚上是否可以安全地在街上拍照，请做一些研究。我建议向该地区的资深街头射击者发送消息，不过您也可以查看有关城市犯罪率的一般文章和统计数据。

使用您对拍摄对象的最佳判断，并考虑带一位朋友一起去。不要在一个地方停留太久，也不要放下装备去更换镜头。最后，如果您希望更加安心，请在出发前为您的装备做好保险！

夜间街拍常见问题解答

晚上拍摄街道安全吗？

这实际上取决于位置和您的方法。夜间街头摄影相对安全，但风险始终存在，因此需要谨慎并采取适当的预防措施。

晚上的街头值得拍照吗？

我想是这样！夜晚的街道看起来非常神奇，呈现出一种全新的形象。

夜间街拍的最佳 ISO 是多少？

我建议在不产生令人难以置信的噪音的情况下将 ISO 调得尽可能高。您需要高 ISO 才能获得相当快的快门速度，而且夜间拍摄时噪点看起来也不错。

夜间街拍应该使用什么相机？

具有较大传感器的紧凑、轻便的相机往往适合夜间街景拍摄。

夜间街拍的最佳焦距是多少？

50mm 焦距是街头摄影的经典，但由于夜间街道往往比较空旷，因此通常可以轻松使用 35mm 或更宽的焦距进行拍摄，以实现更多不寻常的拍摄。

对于大多数摄影师来说，没有什么比在雾中拍摄更好的了。神秘的形状、丝滑的纹理、空灵的光线——这是一种独特的神奇体验，也是拍摄令人惊叹的照片的秘诀。

但捕捉令人惊叹的雾摄影并不总是那么容易。雾气是不可预测的，它可能会导致对焦和清晰度问题，并且通常出现在容易导致相机抖动的低光条件下。要制作最好的雾照片（您经常会发现挂在画廊墙上的那种照片），您需要一个精心策划的方法。您应该在合适的条件下出发，使用最佳的装备，选择完美的设置等等。

幸运的是，作为一名资深的雾天摄影师，我已经制定了很多策略来确保您能够在雾中拍摄出始终如一的精彩照片。在这篇文章中，我分享了我的 13 个最佳技巧 - 所以如果您准备好开始创建空灵、神秘的图像，那么让我们直接开始，从以下开始：

1. 在雾发生之前预测它

雾摄影中最具挑战性的部分是什么？当然是找到雾！在许多地区，雾是罕见的——作为摄影师，你无法控制天气。所以你需要学会提前预测雾气；这样，当合适的条件出现时，您就可以捕捉到美丽的构图。

预测雾的最简单方法是查看天气。雾几乎只发生在早晨，因此每天晚上睡觉前，快速浏览一下您最喜欢的天气应用程序。滚动浏览第二天早上的每小时预测，如果您看到“雾”图标，请选择一个好位置，设置闹钟，并确保在黑暗中出发。

另一种选择是在太阳升起之前醒来，看看外面是否有雾（当然，假设您计划在您家附近拍摄）。这种方法的问题是雾会很快消失，当您确定雾存在时，您可能已经错过了主要活动。

第三个（也是更好的）策略是学会提前预测雾。如果您能够了解导致雾的条件，那么无论天气预报员怎么说，您都可以做好准备。特别是，雾经常发生在以下情况：

  • 地面湿漉漉的（因为前一天下过雨）
  • 气温低
  • 风很弱
  • 天空相对晴朗

请务必特别注意深秋、冬季和早春的天气。虽然从技术上讲，雾可以在一年中的任何时间发生，但在凉爽的季节发生的频率要高得多。

专业提示：如果您想要拍摄特定的镜头并想要检查雾的进展情况，请查看是否可以使用公共网络摄像头对其进行监控。这样，您就可以准确地看到雾的外观以及它是否适合您想要捕捉的图像。

2.带上三脚架和遥控快门

由于雾通常发生在日出时，并且雾往往会严重漫射环境光，因此您绝对应该预料到会出现较暗的情况。场景越暗，您需要降低的快门速度就越低 - 因此，为了防止相机抖动，请确保您同时携带三脚架和遥控快门。

三脚架将使您的相机在 1/60 秒及以下的快门速度下保持稳定。 （如果您打算拍摄长时间曝光的雾气照片，它也会派上用场，我强烈推荐您这样做；请参阅本文其他部分中介绍的提示！）并且当您按下快门按钮时，远程释放将防止相机抖动。 （这不是必需的 - 您可以使用相机的两秒自拍定时器- 但远程释放可以使您的拍摄过程更快、更精确。）

顺便说一句，请确保在拍摄前锁定反光镜（如果您使用的是数码单反相机）。无论您的相机型号如何，都可以使用电子前帘快门模式来防止快门引起的振动。

3.使用手动对焦和窄光圈

在雾中拍摄清晰的照片可能很困难。这就是为什么我鼓励您关闭相机的自动对焦并依靠手动对焦，特别是如果您打算进行有雾的风景摄影。否则，相机的自动对焦系统将难以在低对比度环境中对焦，而您最终可能会感到非常沮丧。

或者，您可以使用相机的自动对焦锁定场景的最高对比度部分，然后旋转镜头的对焦环来微调焦点。

我还鼓励您使用小光圈进行拍摄。光圈越窄， 景深越深，如果您想保持从前景到（雾）背景的清晰度，这一点至关重要。

另外，更深的景深可以提供更大的余地，以防您不小心聚焦在拍摄对象的前面或后面。一个好的起点是 f/8，但如果您正在处理特别深的场景和/或需要更多的误差空间，您总是可以进一步缩小光圈。

请注意，较窄的光圈会减少到达相机传感器的光线量，因此您需要降低快门速度 - 但只要您使用三脚架（请参阅前面的提示！），您应该没问题。

4.尝试简约的方法

雾不仅仅给风景增添了神秘的色彩。它是创建负空间的自然工具，反过来又可以让您简化场景并将焦点放在主题上。换句话说，您可以使用雾作为空白画布来创建美丽的简约镜头。

但这到底是如何运作的呢？在极简主义中，目标是倾向于空虚、负空间，但随后在场景中的某处包含一个清晰的主要主题。因此，通过用纯净的雾气包围你的主要拍摄对象，你可以将观众的目光引导到真正重要的事情上。

请注意，负空间不仅可以简化照片，还可以简化照片。它增加了一层情感。通过使用雾来消除分散注意力的细节，您可以唤起神秘、孤独甚至宁静的感觉。主题周围的空虚增添了一种强大的氛围，从而使整个图像受益。

你不必仅仅停留在孤立你的主题上。雾也让你有机会尝试抽象的构图。通过靠近，尤其是在大雾地区，形状和轮廓可以成为令人兴奋的元素。雾中的一根孤独的树枝或被雾气包围的建筑物可以产生简约的几何形状，从而拍摄出美丽的抽象照片。

底线：当雾来临时，尝试一种简约的方法。专注于场景中简单但引人注目的元素。让雾引导你的眼睛，创造出你可能会忽视的构图。

5. 超越迷雾

如果您想拍摄令人惊叹的雾气景观照片，与其在雾气中工作，不如看看您是否可以超越雾气。寻找各种俯瞰点，确保您在太阳升起时就位，然后拍摄雾气扫过树木和建筑物时的照片：

如果您在正确的时间出现在正确的地点，您甚至可能会捕捉到阳光从上方射入雾气的景象，这看起来绝对是美妙的。

如果您认真对待高角度雾摄影，请考虑购买无人机。这样，无论您是否有良好的有利位置，您都可以拍摄出精美的照片。

还有一点提示：如果您在雾气上方工作，您经常会遇到高动态范围场景，这是许多相机难以捕捉的。确保拍摄一系列包围式图像；这样，如果动态范围确实太大，您始终可以在后期处理中混合多个镜头，以获得曝光良好的最终结果。

6. 采取措施保护您的装备

雾不仅仅是一个美丽的摄影主题；它也是一个美丽的摄影主题。它也是水。它可能会渗入您的设备并造成腐蚀或发霉等损坏。您可能认为防风雨的相机和镜头不会受到影响，但没有一种防风雨密封是完美的，即使是最坚固的装备也容易受到雾相关的损坏。

因此，这里有一个需要遵循的简单规则：拍摄雾时，将相机放在包里，直到准备使用它为止。这都是为了限制暴露在潮湿的环境中。

此外，硅胶是您的相机包中应该随身携带的东西。你可以在网上找到它，或者（如果你问得好的话！）从当地的鞋店购买一些。通过在包的各个隔层中放置几个​​小包，您可以吸收装备带入背包的水分。

专业提示：不要忘记定期更换或再生硅胶，因为它可能会过饱和并停止工作。顺便说一句，手头备有硅胶不仅仅适用于雾摄影；还适用于雾摄影。它对于在热带地区、雨中甚至雪中拍摄也很有用。此外，它的优势还可以扩展到其他敏感配件，例如存储卡和电池。

最后，当您从早上拍摄雾气回到家时，让您的相机包通风。将您的装备放入带有一些硅胶包的密封容器中也是一个明智的选择。

如果您发现自己经常在潮湿的条件下拍摄，请考虑投资一个干燥的柜子。看起来可能很多，但恶劣的天气确实会损坏设备，采取这些预防措施可以让您的设备在未来几年保持平稳运行。

7. 不要忘记普通科目

雾有一种将普通场景变成壮观景象的方式。因此，虽然您可以在雾天拍摄更传统的主题（例如海景和摩天大楼），但您也可以重新审视日常生活、无聊和陈词滥调。

例如，您只需前往当地的公园拍摄树木、香蒲和田野就可以拍摄出精彩的照片。或者，您可以在附近的街道上散步，将相机对准雾气笼罩的路灯、房屋和汽车。

与此相关的是，您可以使用雾来捕获经常拍摄的地点的原始图像。每个人都会拍摄金门大桥，但金门大桥加上一些晨雾可以拍出独特（且壮观）的照片：

8.使用中性密度滤光片

中性密度滤光片旨在阻挡光线。在镜头上安装强效 ND 滤镜，您可以将快门速度降低至 1/10 秒、1 秒，甚至几分钟，而不会出现任何问题 - 即使您在更明亮的条件下工作。

为什么这对于雾摄影有用？好吧，如果你能减慢快门速度，你就可以捕捉到平滑、丝滑的雾气，在风景照片中看起来令人难以置信。长时间曝光的雾看起来像水波：

请注意，ND 滤镜具有多种不同的优点，您需要根据一天中的时间和照明条件来选择滤镜。如果您在太阳升到地平线之前进行拍摄，则可能需要相对较弱的滤镜（或根本不需要滤镜）。但如果您在雾气上方工作并且阳光明媚，您可能需要使用 10 级甚至 15 级滤镜。

专业提示：当您使用 ND 滤镜时，请确保在将滤镜安装到镜头上之前仔细设置构图并对焦。强 ND 滤镜非常暗，因此通过采用这种方法，您可以确保镜头看起来很棒，同时场景在相机取景器中仍然可见。

9.在秋天拍摄

您是否注意到雾似乎与秋季密切相关？ Autumn is a magical time for fog photography, and it's not just because fog is often generated by cooler temperatures. The combination of a foggy mood with the rich colors of fall leaves makes for genuinely breathtaking shots.

In addition to the colors, autumn offers unique subjects that pair well with the fog ambiance. Falling leaves, harvest themes, withering plants, and Halloween vibes all go great with fog, due to the sense of nostalgia, the emphasis on endings, and even the spookiness.

So when fall rolls around, make sure you take advantage of any foggy days! To get started, try photographing in forests when fall colors are at their peak and see how the combination of gray fog and colorful leaves creates visually striking images.

Additionally, think about the specific details that come alive in the fall. Dew-kissed spider webs, mist-covered fields, and solitary structures all take on a unique beauty in the fog. Allow the combination of fog and fall to guide your creative eye, and capture some wonderful – and wonderfully moody! – images.

10. Try a mix of wide-angle and telephoto fog compositions

Wide-angle lenses are most photographers' go-to for fog shots, and understandably so: the sweeping views you can achieve with these lenses are often instantly arresting to the viewer. In other words, a wide-angle perspective can capture the grandeur of a fog-covered landscape in a way that's both breathtaking and immersive.

But don't let your fog photography start and end with wide-angle compositions. Telephoto lenses may not be the most obvious choice to capture a foggy forest, but trust me when I say that they offer a wonderful perspective.

In particular, telephoto focal lengths – in the 70-200mm range – are perfect for more intimate fog images. Try focusing on specific details like a lone tree standing in a foggy field or the delicate dew on a spider web. At 200mm, you can isolate the subjects among the fog and create a powerful composition that draws the viewer in.

You can also capture photos of distant landscapes using a 70-200mm lens. These longer focal lengths can compress space, making the fog appear denser and giving your landscape shots an enhanced level of moodiness:

And, above all, don't be afraid to experiment with different focal lengths. Mix wide-angle with telephoto shots. Try working with a standard 50mm lens. Try different perspectives. Each approach will offer unique shots of the fog, resulting in a rich and diverse collection of images!

11. Experiment with different shutter speeds

While I've spent time discussing the benefits of long-exposure techniques for fog photography, it's important to avoid keeping the shutter open for too long. Because while lengthy shutter speeds can certainly create stunning ethereal effects, they can also make the fog lose its shape and turn into a flat mess.

That's why I encourage you to experiment with different shutter speeds whenever possible. If you're confronted by a foggy scene and you have the time, test out a few different settings, then view the results on your LCD. Sometimes, you might like the slower version – but other times, the faster version will look the best!

And don't shy away from relatively quick shutter speeds, either. A fast shutter speed – such as 1/60s or even 1/125s – will give the fog more texture, which can also look great.

12. Keep photographing until the fog is gone

Fog is an ever-changing phenomenon. One moment it's dense and mysterious; the next, it's lifting to reveal a spectacular landscape. So don't pack up your camera just because the fog seems to be lifting. Keep seeking out compositions, keep shooting, and you might just be rewarded with some stunning scenes.

As the fog fades, you'll need to keep an eye on your camera settings, as it can be easy to accidentally overexpose your shots as the sunlight starts to shine through. You can also try different camera settings to explore unique effects. Don't be afraid to adjust your aperture or exposure as the light changes with the fog's movements!

Patience is a real virtue in fog photography. Keep your camera at the ready and watch as the various stages of a foggy cityscape or landscape unfold. You never know when a truly once-in-a-lifetime scene will present itself, especially at sunrise or sunset as beams of light break through the foggy environment.

Pro tip: Don't forget to check a weather app on your phone every hour or so. It can provide valuable information about the fog's potential movements and density. The more adaptable you can be, the more you'll maximize the potential of a foggy day!

13. Edit your fog photos for the best results

If you're serious about creating top-notch fog photos, editing shouldn't just be seen as a method for correcting poorly captured images; instead, view it as a way to take a great image and make it truly spectacular. Get in the habit of sorting through your images after every shoot, identifying your best files, and then spending time editing each one.

Start by experimenting with basic adjustments like contrast, exposure, and white balance. These tweaks can keep the colors and details looking natural, and they can also help balance the emptiness of the shot with the main subject to create a more compelling composition.

Local adjustments such as dodging and burning can accentuate details in the fog. They can even be used to add depth to the fog itself, and while you'll need to build up the adjustments slowly and subtly, the results can be spectacular.

Color grading is another creative tool at your disposal. Enhance the mood of the foggy scene by playing with different color tones. The right hue can elevate the emotions and atmosphere captured in your image, so take your time to find what resonates.

And no matter what, don't shy away from trying something new. While there are standard adjustments that are frequently effective, you can never know for certain what will really level up a fog shot.

Remember, you don't need to be a Photoshop wizard to make these changes. Many beginner-friendly tools – like Lightroom and Luminar – can help you achieve professional results. The key is to practice, play around, and most of all, have fun with the process. Your fog photographs will only get better as you grow more comfortable with editing.

Fog photography tips: final words

Fog photography is an incredible opportunity to stretch your creative muscles, and by following the simple guidelines I've laid out, you'll find yourself producing gorgeous shots that really do communicate the mood and feel of a foggy scene.

And keep in mind that you don't need to be a professional or own the latest gear to capture great shots. All you need is your passion, a sense of adventure, and the willingness to see the world through a foggy lens.

Even if you struggle at first, don't give up. Refer back to this article, figure out what you need to do to improve your results, and keep shooting!

Looking to master macro photography so you can capture pro-level shots of flowers, leaves, products, and so much more? While most beginners – and even experienced photographers – struggle to create magazine-worthy macro images, it's nowhere near as difficult as it might seem.

I started taking macro photos when I was 15, and I spent the next decade developing tips, tricks, and strategies that everyone can use for great results. In this article, I share all the basics plus some of my favorite advanced techniques to really level up your images. Specifically, I discuss:

  • The two essential pieces of gear you need to take stunning close-up shots
  • The best macro lighting for vibrant colors
  • How to create a scrumptious, creamy background blur
  • How to capture consistently sharp macro images
  • So much more!

Ready to start capturing breathtaking photos of the macro world? Let's dive right in.

What is macro photography?

Macro photography refers to photographing at high magnifications . This may involve the use of a specialized macro lens, which is designed to capture detailed, close-up photos.

Technically speaking, a true macro photo creates an image on the camera sensor that's the same size as the scene in real life, also known as 1:1 magnification. So if you were to photograph an inch-long flower, the flower would need to take up an inch of your camera sensor.

Common macro photography subjects

It's a popular misconception to pigeonhole macro photography into a single genre. Rather, it's an approach to image-making that reveals the fascinating intricacies usually overlooked by the casual observer.

Therefore, macro photography spans a wide range of subjects and can be used in diverse photographic fields. A large number of macro photographers focus on the natural world, using close-up techniques to capture the intricate details of flowers, the delicate veins in leaves, or the vivid colors and patterns of insects.

That said, it's not just nature photography that benefits from a macro approach. Product photographers use macro techniques to highlight tiny details of products to show the finesse and care that goes into their creation. And even a casual photographer might enjoy capturing macro shots of everyday items around the house; here, the macro lens can tease out textures, lines, and colors that are often overlooked, resulting in arresting images.

If you're new to macro photography, it's always a good idea to start with a more conventional approach. But remember, the joy of photography is experimentation and finding your unique point of view. Feel free to explore unconventional subjects and discover new ways of seeing the world!

Essential macro photography gear

Getting started with macro photography is easy, and you don't need thousands of dollars worth of gear.

Instead, I generally recommend that beginners purchase two items:

  1. A camera
  2. A close-focusing accessory

It's a minimalistic kit, sure, and there are certainly other pieces of equipment that can be useful (which I discuss in detail below). But it's the setup I've used for most of my macro photography career, and it's a great way to delve into the macro approach without breaking the bank.

Let's take a look at both these pieces of equipment in greater detail:

Choosing a camera

It may seem blatantly obvious, but every macro photographer needs a camera.

What kind of camera should you buy? The best macro photography cameras offer interchangeable lenses; these tend to produce the highest-quality photos, and as you become more experienced, you can upgrade your lenses without needing to purchase a new camera. Plus, interchangeable lenses will just make your life a lot easier if you ever decide to shoot landscapes, portraits, architecture, etc., because you can buy lenses specifically for those purposes.

But as long as your camera can change lenses, you don't need to be picky. Any DSLR or mirrorless model from Canon, Nikon, Sony, Fujifilm, Panasonic, Olympus, or Pentax will work just fine (and there are plenty of other brands not mentioned on that list that will work, too).

And if you don't want to shell out for a DSLR or mirrorless camera , that's okay, too. Even a smartphone will let you shoot macro photos, provided you have the right close-focusing accessory, as discussed in the next section:

Choosing a close-focusing accessory

Most cameras cannot automatically focus up close. So in order to capture macro photos, you'll need some sort of magnifier .

Here, you have a few options:

Close-up filters: an affordable starting point

Need a quick, cost-effective way to get your feet wet in macro photography? Try close-up filters . These nifty tools are essentially little magnifying glasses for your lens, and they mount onto the end of an existing lens (such as a standard 18-55mm kit lens or a 50mm prime ).

One of the best things about close-up filters is their affordability. They offer a very inexpensive entry point into the world of macro photography, making them an appealing option for beginners.

But like most things in life, you get what you pay for. Close-up filters have two main drawbacks: reduced optical quality and limited flexibility. Images taken with close-up filters tend to lack that next-level crispness that serious macro shooters love, and the filters impose a maximum focus distance on your lens, so you can't capture images from a variety of distances.

Extension tubes: a small step up

Next up are extension tubes , the cylindrical spacers that fit between your camera and the lens, pushing the lens further from the camera sensor. An extension tube or two allows your lens to focus much closer than usual, creating a magnified image on the sensor.

Extension tubes are pricier than close-up filters, yet they offer an affordable and arguably higher-quality option for those dipping their toes into macro photography.

The downside? They can make quickly switching between subjects or different magnification levels a bit challenging. And while they technically don't degrade image quality, lenses that aren't designed for close focusing often aren't as sharp at high magnifications. So you may still notice a reduction in image quality.

Reversing rings: cheap but limited

Next up is a somewhat unusual but budget-friendly option: reversing rings . These special adapters allow you to mount a lens on your camera backward. This simple adjustment effectively turns your lens into a magnifying glass, producing a macro effect.

Reversing rings offer a cheap and intriguing way to dabble in macro photography, but they share the same disadvantages as close-up filters and extension tubes: a potential loss in optical quality and a significant drop in shooting flexibility. Be sure to keep these limitations in mind when considering this option.

A dedicated macro lens: the premium choice

Lastly, let's discuss the cream of the crop for macro photography optics: a dedicated macro lens. This piece of gear is specifically designed for macro photography and offers unparalleled sharpness and flexibility. Whether you want to create ultra-detailed shots at high magnifications or you're looking for a powerful lens that can do a mixture of close-up and standard photography, a macro lens is a solid choice.

While these lenses carry a heftier price tag, there are affordable options on the market that don't sacrifice quality. They're a worthy investment for beginners serious about macro photography or enthusiasts looking to take their shots to the next level.

There are plenty of great macro lenses to choose from , but the macro lens you buy doesn't have to be the most expensive or top-of-the-line model. What really matters is its ability to get you close to the subject. Ideally, look for lenses that offer 1:1 magnification for life-size images. However, a lens offering 1:2 magnification can also do a pretty decent job, particularly if capturing tiny details isn't your main objective.

And don't forget to consider the focal length based on your subjects of interest. A lens in the 80-120mm range is versatile and popular among flower, product, and still-life photographers. But if you're keen on photographing insects, a longer macro lens in the 150-200mm range lets you keep a respectful distance.

Finally, for a more budget-friendly and versatile option, a shorter lens in the 30-60mm range works well for a mix of macro and everyday shooting.

Optional macro photography gear

There are a few items that some dedicated macro photographers like to use, yet they're certainly not essential for certain types of macro shooting.

In fact, there are plenty of high-level macro photographers, myself included, who rarely use this type of equipment. But some (or all) of these additional products are necessary if you want to capture certain types of macro photos, like indoor product shots or photos with an extremely deep depth of field, so it's certainly worth considering.

If you want my recommendation, I would suggest getting started without these accessories. Later on, you may want to consider purchasing them as you identify the types of images that you really want to shoot. But if you're serious about delving into a specific genre of macro photography right from the start, then here are the items you'll want to consider:

A tripod will keep your setup stable at high magnifications, and it becomes essential if you want to capture macro images where subjects are sharp from front to back.

You see, in order to achieve such a deep depth of field, you'll be working with an ultra-narrow aperture, which usually results in a longer shutter speed. In that scenario, a tripod is really the only way to prevent blur due to camera shake.

You generally also need a tripod if you're using a technique called focus stacking . With this method, you'll have to maintain a single frame while capturing multiple shots. A tripod ensures that your camera stays in the same position throughout the process.

Now, if you decide to invest in a tripod, go for a reasonably lightweight one. Carbon fiber is your best bet for material, especially if you plan to photograph outdoors. On the other hand, if you only want to photograph in the studio, a heavy aluminum tripod will cost you less without sacrificing stability.

Additionally, look for a tripod that offers flexibility so you can position your camera at all sorts of angles. Ideally, you should purchase one with independently adjustable legs that can get down to just a few inches off the ground.

A macro focusing rail

This accessory might sound a bit technical, but a macro focusing rail can save you a lot of time and effort. It mounts between the tripod and the camera, allowing you to subtly adjust your camera's position by moving it along the rail track. If you've ever found yourself spending lots of time adjusting your tripod position and tripod head angle to nail focus, this tool might be your solution.

A macro focusing rail is particularly handy for focus stacking your macro images. You can set your macro lens to its maximum magnification, frame your shot, and then slowly move your entire camera setup forward or backward while capturing a series of images.

A macro flash

Lighting can be quite challenging in macro photography. For one, increasing the magnification on a lens reduces the light that reaches the camera sensor. Add to that the need to use an ultra-narrow aperture for deep depth of field, and you'll often find yourself needing extra light on your subject. That's where a flash comes in handy.

The most popular type of flash among macro photographers is the ring flash. It encircles the front of the lens and casts an even light on the subject. This prevents shadows from being created by the lens barrel, providing balanced illumination.

There are also other forms of flash for macro photography, like twin flashes, which have two heads mounted on either side of the lens.

But I'll be honest with you; I don't like to use flashes in my macro photography. Even with diffusers, ring flashes can create results that are too harsh for my taste.

However, if you plan to do indoor studio macro photography, some form of flash becomes essential. A macro-specific flash is the only way I know that you can light your subject from the front without those pesky shadows.

Note: There is one type of artificial lighting for macro photography that I haven't tried yet, which offers flexible arms that can be positioned independently around your subject. This might be something worth exploring if you are looking to experiment with artificial lighting in your macro photography.

Macro photography settings

Macro photography, while often very artistic, is a technically demanding genre. At high magnifications, light is limited, camera shake is magnified, and setting focus can be a challenge.

For the best results, you need to pay careful attention to your settings when shooting. Here are my three essential recommendations:

1. Set your camera to Aperture Priority or Manual mode

Pretty much every camera offers a series of modes: Aperture Priority, Shutter Priority, Program, etc.

And I highly recommend choosing either Aperture Priority or Manual mode .

Aperture Priority lets you choose your aperture and ISO setting, while your camera chooses the shutter speed. I discuss aperture more in the next section, but taking control over the aperture goes a long way toward creating stunning macro photos.

Manual mode lets you choose the aperture, the shutter speed, and the ISO. Personally, I shoot almost exclusively in Manual mode, as I find it offers the most flexibility and creative control. It can take some getting used to, though, so if you like the idea of shooting in Manual mode but don't feel comfortable adjusting all your camera settings, start with Aperture Priority, then switch to Manual as you become more experienced.

2. Carefully choose your aperture for perfect depth of field

The aperture is a hole inside your lens that opens and closes depending on your camera's aperture setting.

Aperture is a key part of exposure (along with shutter speed and ISO). But aperture also affects the depth of field : the amount of your image that's sharp.

By selecting a small aperture (also known as a high f-number, such as f/16), you'll end up with a result like this one, where most of the subject is in focus:

And by selecting a large aperture (ie, a small f-number, such as f/2.8), you'll end up with an image like this, where very little of the subject is in focus:

Because macro photography occurs at such high magnifications, depth of field is already pretty limited. (The closer you are to your subject, the smaller the depth of field, all else being equal.)

So it's pretty tough to get a shot with a sharp subject and a sharp background, even if you shoot at f/22. However, you'll still need to carefully consider your aperture. Certain macro photographers like to keep their entire subject sharp from front to back, and they'll often shoot at f/13 or f/16.

Whereas other macro photographers like to create a so-called soft-focus effect , where you only get a sliver of your subject in focus.

Neither choice is wrong, and both types of macro photography can look great when executed properly. Just make sure you're thinking about the aperture for every shot you take. That way, you get the artistic result you're after.

3. Use manual focusing for the sharpest results

These days, cameras and lenses offer amazing autofocus systems. You can capture birds in flight, cars at high speeds, airplanes taking off, and so much more.

Yet even the best autofocus systems come with a major weakness:

High-magnification focusing.

Unfortunately, autofocusing on objects at macro magnifications is just really hard. Which is why, for the best macro photos, you'll need to focus manually.

This may sound intimidating, but it's actually quite easy. Simply switch your lens from autofocus to manual focus (most lenses have a switch on their side). Then turn the focus ring until you achieve the point of focus you're after.

You'll get the hang of it pretty quickly. And pretty soon, you'll want to focus manually all the time!

(Quick tip: If you're struggling to focus on a close-up subject, try setting your focus first . Then let go of your focus ring and rock your camera back and forth until the plane of focus is exactly where you want it.)

Macro photography lighting

For macro photography, I recommend you start with natural light . Don't buy any flashes or studio strobes or ring lights, especially not at first.

Instead, take advantage of the sun and all it offers. Here are the two best times of day to do outdoor macro photography:

Cloudy midday

Cloudy light is great for macro photography. It's soft, it's flattering, and it makes colors look super vibrant.

Here's a photo I took on a cloudy afternoon:

Do you see how the colors really pop? That's thanks to the cloudy lighting.

Unfortunately, cloudy light early and late in the day doesn't work so well – the sky will be dark, and you'll struggle to get a nice, bright image. So if the sky is cloudy, make sure to head out toward the middle of the day.

Sunny mornings and evenings

The golden hours – that is, the first hour or two after sunrise and the last hour or two before sunset – are beloved by pretty much all photographers, and for good reason:

They offer soft golden light that looks magnificent .

Thanks to golden hour lighting, I love doing macro photography early in the morning and late in the day. Colors look beautiful, and you can create all sorts of interesting lighting effects:
